comments:
This class discusses how great works of literature from different cultural traditions have reclaimed and reinterpreted compelling religious themes. One religious tradition will be emphasized each time the course is taught.

The majority of students stated that this course was “fascinating.” However, a few students disagreed and said that “the course... was sort of a let down.” Students also lauded the “GREAT books on the syllabus,” but were frustrated by being forced to rush through each book in a week. One student said, “I also think some books were not as salient from the course and contributed to the rushed schedule.”  

Students praised Professor Struck for his dedication to the class and his work. As one student said, “Professor Struck’s obvious passion for the works he teaches shines through during lecture and discussions.” The majority of students agreed with one student’s summation of the teaching: “I would have liked a little more teaching/lecturing from the professor and a little less class discussion, since I gained a great deal more from the lecture portions of the class.”

Many students complained about the abundance of readings. One student noted that “there are almost too many readings – it would be nice to have a few less and have more time to discuss and read each assignment.” Another student said, “the readings were great; however, the teachers should consider cutting the amount of texts to be read in order to be able to go into the texts in a deeper manner.” A few students said that “the grading was a little harsh” and that “It also would have been very helpful to make the final paper due during finals rather than on the last day of class, since that week and the preceding week is notoriously hectic for exams, projects, and presentations.”

This class discusses how great works of literature from different cultural traditions have reclaimed and reinterpreted compelling religious themes. One religious tradition will be emphasized each time the course is taught.

The majority of students stated that this course was “fascinating.” However, a few students disagreed and said that “the course... was sort of a let down.” Students also lauded the “GREAT books on the syllabus,” but were frustrated by being forced to rush through each book in a week. One student said, “I also think some books were not as salient from the course and contributed to the rushed schedule.” 

Students stated that Professor Matter was “a little less engaging than Professor Struck, but both were fantastic.” However, one student said “sometimes it felt like Professor Matter came into class without a clear goal or lesson plan, which made it much harder to focus and take her seriously.” The majority of students agreed with one student’s summation of the teaching: “I would have liked a little more teaching/lecturing from the professors and a little less class discussion since I gained a great deal more from the lecture portions of the class.”

Many students complained about the abundance of readings. One student noted that “there are almost too many readings – it would be nice to have a few less and have more time to discuss and read each assignment.” Another student said, “the readings were great; however, the teachers should consider cutting the amount of texts to be read in order to be able to go into the texts in a deeper manner.” A few students said that “the grading was a little harsh” and that “It also would have been very helpful to make the final paper due during finals rather than on the last day of class, since that week and the preceding week is notoriously hectic for exams, projects, and presentations.”
